questions.text: A 28-year-old male with no significant medical history presents for a routine health check-up. He is a non-smoker and leads an active lifestyle. On examination, his heart rate is recorded as 84 beats per minute and his blood pressure is 128/80 mm Hg. The clinician decides to calculate his mean arterial pressure (MAP). What is the MAP for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 96 mm Hg

 

Option C:

 

  • Using the formula MAP = Diastolic Pressure + 1/3(Pulse Pressure),
  • With Pulse Pressure = 128 mm Hg - 80 mm Hg,
  • MAP ≈ 80 mm Hg + 1/3 (48 mm Hg) ≈ 96 mm Hg.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A : Incorrect. This represents Pulse Pressure

 

Pulse Pressure = Systolic Pressure - Diastolic Pressure = 128 – 80 = 48 mm Hg

 

Option B and Option D: Incorrect. these options do not correctly apply the MAP calculation formula with the given blood pressure values.

 

Option D : Incorrect. This overestimates the MAP. The calculation using the given blood pressure values does not result in this value.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective of this question is to assess the ability to calculate mean arterial pressure using systolic and diastolic blood pressure readings, an essential skill in evaluating cardiovascular risk and hemodynamic status.

 

Refer: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia Edition, Pg No : 255

choices.text: The initial active ejection period is responsible for 50% of ventricular blood emptying.
The rapid ejection phase corresponds to the late and passive of the ejection period.
The majority of ventricular emptying occurs during the rapid ejection phase in the first half of the ejection period.
The slow ejection phase dominates the initial two-thirds of the early ejection period, contributing to most of the ventricular emptying.

questions.text: In an advanced cardiology seminar focused on the intricacies of ventricular ejection dynamics, the facilitator presents a challenging question to assess the understanding of ejection phase characteristics. Given the complexities of ventricular ejection during the cardiac cycle, which of the following assertions is accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The majority of ventricular emptying occurs during the rapid ejection phase in the first half of the ejection period.

 

Option C. Correct: The rapid ejection phase, occurring shortly after the onset of ventricular systole i.e after Isovolumetric contaction, accounts for the majority of ventricular blood emptying and typically takes place in the first half of the ejection period, making this statement accurate.

 

  • During the ventricular contraction, around 66-70% of the atrial emptying of the blood will take place in the active/ early/ rapid period of ejection (not 50%)

  • The atrial emptying of the remaining 30-33% of blood will take place during the slow/ late/ passive of the period of ejection

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. The initial active ejection period sees significant blood emptying,  around 66 to 70% of the emptying of the blood will take place in the active/ early/ rapid period of ejection (not 50%).

 

Option B. Incorrect. The rapid ejection phase is late and passive to the final third of the ejection period; it primarily occurs early/ active ejection period, following the onset of ventricular systole and preceding the slow ejection phase.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Active/early/rapid ejection period, contributes to most of the ventricular emptying i.e 66 to 70 %  and it  dominates the slow ejection phase and not vice cersa

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the phases of ventricular ejection during the cardiac cycle, emphasizing the timing and significance of the rapid and slow ejection phases.

 

Refer: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia Edition, Pg No : 212

choices.text: Atrial systole
Passive atrial emptying
Isovolumetric contraction
Isovolumetric relaxation

questions.text: In an advanced cardiology seminar focusing on the nuances of heart sounds and their correlation with the cardiac cycle phases, participants are asked to identify the phase associated with the third heart sound (S3). Considering the detailed timing and hemodynamics of the cardiac cycle, which phase is S3 most closely associated with?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Passive atrial emptying

 

Option B. The third heart sound (S3) occurs shortly after the second heart sound during the Passive atrial emptying also known as rapid filling phase of the ventricles. It is thought to result from the vibrations of the ventricular walls due to the rapid influx of blood from the atria, especially in the context of ventricular compliance changes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. Atrial systole corresponds to the late phase of ventricular filling, just before ventricular systole, and is typically associated with the fourth heart sound (S4), not the third heart sound (S3).

 

Option C. Incorrect. Isovolumetric contraction is the phase following atrial systole, where the ventricles contract with no change in volume and no ejection yet, marked by the first heart sound (S1). It is not associated with S3.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Isovolumetric relaxation occurs right after the ejection phase, marked by the closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves and before the rapid filling phase. It precedes the occurrence of S3 and is associated with the second heart sound (S2).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify the rapid filling phase of the ventricles as the phase associated with the third heart sound (S3) in the cardiac cycle.

Top of Form

 

Mechanisms of different heart sounds:

 

 

Refer: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia Edition, Pg No : 213

choices.text: Mild environmental temperature fluctuations – Cardiac output remains stable
Physical exertion – Cardiac output escalates
Congestive heart failure on both sides of the heart – Cardiac output diminishes
Tachyarrhythmias – Cardiac output surges

questions.text: In a clinical cardiology training session focusing on the physiologic and pathophysiologic determinants of cardiac output, participants are presented with scenarios depicting various conditions and their typical effects on cardiac output. They are tasked with identifying the mismatched pair in terms of the condition's usual impact on cardiac output:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tachyarrhythmias – Cardiac output surges

 

Option D. Incorrect. Rapid arrhythmias, particularly those that significantly increase heart rate, can actually decrease cardiac output. This is due to the shortened diastolic filling time, which reduces the volume of blood ejected with each heartbeat, contrary to the increase suggested in this option.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Correct. Mild changes in environmental temperature typically do not induce significant alterations in cardiac output, as the body's thermoregulatory mechanisms effectively maintain cardiovascular homeostasis without necessitating changes in cardiac output.

 

Option B. Correct. During exercise, the body's demand for oxygen and nutrients rises, leading to an increase in cardiac output. This is achieved through heightened heart rate and stroke volume, facilitating enhanced blood flow to active muscles.

 

Option C. Correct. In cases of biventricular failure, both the left and right sides of the heart are unable to pump blood effectively, resulting in reduced cardiac output. This condition leads to inadequate perfusion and accumulation of fluid, manifesting as congestive symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Discern the impact of various physiological and pathological conditions on cardiac output, emphasizing the importance of heart rate and ventricular filling in determining cardiac performance.

 

  • Other important factors affecting cardiac output:

 

 

Refer: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg No: 544

choices.text: Preload increases with a decrease in the volume of blood at the end of systole.
Preload is directly related to the volume of blood in the ventricles at the end of diastole.
Preload decreases as the ventricular volume at the end of diastole increases.
Preload is unaffected by changes in the volume of blood at the end of systole.

questions.text: In an advanced clinical discussion centered around the determinants of cardiac performance, a complex question is posed to assess the understanding of preload and its relationship with ventricular volumes. Given the fundamental principles of cardiac physiology, which of the following statements correctly describes the relationship between them?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Preload is directly related to the volume of blood in the ventricles at the end of diastole.

 

Option B. Preload refers to the initial stretching of the cardiac myocytes prior to contraction and is directly proportional to the end-diastolic volume. A higher end-diastolic volume stretches the ventricular walls more, leading to a greater preload according to the Frank-Starling mechanism.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. Preload is not determined by the volume of blood remaining in the ventricles at the end of systole (end-systolic volume); rather, it is influenced by the volume of blood in the ventricles at the end of diastole, which sets the initial stretch of the ventricular myocardium before contraction.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Preload actually increases with an increase in end-diastolic volume. The relationship is direct, not inverse, as preload is determined by the ventricular end-diastolic pressure, which is a function of end-diastolic volume.

 

Option D. Incorrect. While preload is primarily concerned with the volume at the end of diastole, end-systolic volume can indirectly affect preload by influencing the subsequent filling of the ventricles; however, preload is more directly related to end-diastolic volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clarify the concept of preload in the heart, highlighting its direct proportionality to end-diastolic volume and its pivotal role in determining the initial stretch of the ventricular myocardium before contraction.

 

Refer: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg No: 546

choices.text: Aortic regurgitation.
Mitral regurgitation.
Aortic stenosis.
Congestive cardiac failure.

questions.text: In a cardiology research seminar, fellows are analyzing the changes in pressure-volume loops and their implications for various cardiac conditions. A key concept being discussed is the leftward shift of the pressure-volume loop and its clinical significance. Based on the characteristics of different cardiac pathologies, which condition is typically associated with a shift shown in the pressure-volume loop?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortic stenosis

 

Option C. Correct. Aortic stenosis leads to a leftward shift of the pressure-volume loop because the left ventricle generates higher pressures during systole to overcome the resistance of the stenotic aortic valve, which increases afterload and decreases end-systolic volume.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. In aortic regurgitation, the pressure-volume loop is typically shows right shift; instead, there is a regurgitant volume leading to a larger loop due to the increased end-diastolic volume.

 

Option B. Incorrect. Mitral regurgitation also does not cause a leftward shift in the pressure-volume loop; it causes an increase in the end-diastolic volume due to the backward flow of blood into the left atrium during systole leading to right shift.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Congestive cardiac failure usually causes a rightward shift of the pressure-volume loop due to decreased myocardial contractility and an increase in end-diastolic volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the interpretation of pressure-volume loops in cardiac pathologies, where a leftward shift is indicative of conditions like aortic stenosis, which involve increased afterload and higher pressures at lower ventricular volumes.

 

Refer: Ganongs Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg No: 540

choices.text: Phase 0 - Rapid influx of Na+ ions.
Phase 2 - Plateau phase due to Ca2+ influx and K+ efflux.
Phase 4 - Spontaneous depolarization due to mixed Na+/K+ current.
Phase 1 - Initial repolarization due to K+ efflux

questions.text: In a cardiology seminar focusing on the electrophysiology of the heart, a question is posed to delve into the understanding of the action potential of the nodal tissue. Participants are asked to identify the phase and corresponding ionic changes that predominantly characterize the action potential of this tissue. Which of the following options accurately reflects this?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phase 4 - Spontaneous depolarization due to mixed Na+/K+ current.

 

Option C. Phase 4 in nodal tissues, particularly the SA node, is characterized by spontaneous depolarization, which is primarily driven by a mixed Na+/K+ current, often referred to as the 'funny current' (If), along with a gradual Ca2+ influx.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. Phase 0 in nodal tissues is not characterized by a rapid influx of Na+ ions as it is in myocardial cells. Instead, the upstroke of the nodal action potential is primarily due to Ca2+ influx.

 

Option B. Incorrect. The plateau phase, or Phase 2, is a feature of the action potential in myocardial cells, not nodal tissues. Nodal tissue action potentials lack a distinct plateau phase.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Phase 1, or initial repolarization, is not a distinct phase in the action potential of nodal tissues. This phase is more relevant to the action potential of atrial and ventricular myocardial cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the unique characteristics of the action potential in cardiac nodal tissues, emphasizing the role of the mixed Na+/K+ current in spontaneous depolarization during Phase 4.

 

 

Refer: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia Edition, Pg No : 182

choices.text: L-type calcium channels are responsible for the rapid depolarization seen in phase 0 of the ventricular myocyte action potential.
L-type calcium channels facilitate the late influx of potassium ions during phase 2, the plateau phase, of the ventricular action potential.
L-type calcium channels initiate the action potential in ventricular myocytes by allowing sodium ions to enter rapidly during phase 0.
L-type calcium channels contribute to the plateau phase by permitting a sustained influx of calcium ions during phase 2 of the ventricular action potential.

questions.text: During a cardiology fellowship roundtable discussion, a challenging clinical case involving the pharmacological management of a patient with ventricular tachycardia prompts an in-depth analysis of cardiac ion channel physiology. Given the nuances of ion channel function in cardiac myocytes, which of the following statements accurately reflects the characteristics and role of L-type calcium channels in the cardiac action potential?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) L-type calcium channels contribute to the plateau phase by permitting a sustained influx of calcium ions during phase 2 of the ventricular action potential.

 

Option D. L-type calcium channels open during phase 2 of the ventricular action potential, allowing calcium to enter the cell (Influx), (while the K+ efflux simultaneously continues), which prolongs the depolarization phase and contributes to the characteristic plateau phase of the cardiac action potential.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. The rapid depolarization seen in phase 0 of the ventricular myocyte action potential is primarily due to the opening of voltage-gated sodium channels, not L-type calcium channels.

 

Option B. Incorrect. L-type calcium channels are responsible for calcium influx, not potassium influx, and they contribute to phase 2 of the action potential, which maintains the plateau phase, not initiating it.

 

Option C. Incorrect. The initiation of the action potential in ventricular myocytes is due to the rapid entry of sodium ions through voltage-gated sodium channels, not through L-type calcium channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the function and importance of L-type calcium channels in the plateau phase of the ventricular myocyte action potential.

 

Refer: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia Edition, Pg No : 182

choices.text: The rapid repolarization phase due to the transient outward potassium current.
The presence of fast sodium channels that recover quickly after inactivation.
The sustained influx of calcium ions during the plateau phase of the action potential.
The delayed closure of voltage-gated potassium channels after repolarization.

questions.text: In a clinical case discussion on cardiac physiology, a seasoned cardiologist presents a complex scenario to a group of residents. The case involves a patient with an atypical arrhythmia, prompting a discussion on the refractory period of cardiac muscle cells and their resistance to tetanization. Which factor contributes to the long refractory period of cardiac muscle cells, thereby preventing tetanization?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The sustained influx of calcium ions during the plateau phase of the action potential.

 

Option C. The prolonged plateau phase, which is due to the sustained influx of calcium ions, extends the refractory period of cardiac muscle cells. This prevents the re-initiation of an action potential and thus prevents tetanization.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. The transient outward potassium current contributes to early repolarization but does not extend the refractory period sufficiently to prevent tetanization.

 

Option B. Incorrect. Fast sodium channels recover relatively quickly after inactivation, which would not be conducive to a long refractory period. It is their rapid inactivation that helps initiate the refractory period, but not its length.

 

Option D. Incorrect. While the closure of voltage-gated potassium channels is part of repolarization, it is the duration of the calcium influx during the plateau phase that primarily contributes to the long refractory period in cardiac muscle cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the role of the prolonged plateau phase, mediated by calcium influx, in establishing the long refractory period of cardiac muscle cells, which prevents tetanization.

 

(Refer: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition, pg no: 179)

choices.text: Epicardium to Endocardium
Endocardium to Epicardium
Base to Apex
Right to left

questions.text: A challenging case involving a 58-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease is presented. The patient underwent a detailed cardiac assessment, including an advanced imaging study that highlighted the Depolarization process within the myocardium. Which of the following is correct directionality of depolarization across the myocardial wall, a key factor in interpreting complex cardiac imaging and electrocardiographic data.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endocardium to Epicardium

 

Option B. Depolarization in the heart generally proceeds from the endocardium to the epicardium, reflecting the sequence of electrical recovery that follows the initial depolarization wave, ensuring efficient cardiac function and coordination.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. Repolarization proceeds from the epicardium to the endocardium, (not the depolarization) which is contrary to the normal physiological process observed in cardiac tissue, where the repolarization wave moves from the inner layers outward.

 

Option C. Incorrect. The Base to Apex is more characteristic of repolarization spread and does not accurately describe the general process of myocardial repolarization across the ventricular wall.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Right-to-left movement does not represent the typical repolarization pattern in the ventricular myocardium and does not align with the established understanding of cardiac electrophysiology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the normal direction of depolarization in the heart's ventricular myocardium, which proceeds from the endocardium to the epicardium.

 

Refer: Ganongs Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg No: 523

choices.text: Apex of the heart → Base of the heart → Interventricular groove → Around the AV nodal region
Base of the heart → Around the AV nodal region → Interventricular groove → Apex of the heart
Around the AV nodal region → Interventricular groove → Apex of the heart → Base of the heart
Apex of the heart → Interventricular groove → Around the AV nodal region → Base of the heart

questions.text: In the case of a 57-year-old patient with a unique pattern of ventricular repolarization after myocardial infarction highlighted by advanced imaging techniques is discussed. The physician is asked to determine the correct sequence of repolarization across various regions of the ventricles based on the presented data.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Base of the heart → Around the AV nodal region → Interventricular groove → Apex of the heart

 

Option B. The sequence starts with the Base of the heart, reflecting the epicardium to endocardial toward apex of ventricle during repolarization. The interventricular groove will follow repolarization of the region around the AV node before ending at the apex of the heart, which is the last to repolarize.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. While the apex is incorrectly identified as the starting point. The base of the heart repolarizes in the beginning, not after the apex; the interventricular groove and AV nodal region following the base does not align with the typical repolarization pattern.

 

Option C. Incorrect. The sequence does not start around the AV nodal region or the interventricular groove. The correct sequence initiates at the base.

 

Option D. Incorrect. This sequence is reversed; repolarization typically begins at the Base and moves towards the Apex, not the other way around.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the typical sequence of ventricular repolarization, beginning at the Base and moving towards the apex, with the epicardial surfaces repolarizing before the endocardial surfaces.

 

Refer: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia Edition, Pg No : 205

choices.text: 1-->2-->3--> 4
1-->2-->4--> 3
2-->3-->1-->4
2-->3-->4-->1

questions.text:
In a recent cardiology conference, a complex case of a 65-year-old male with heart failure was presented, focusing on the interpretation of his jugular venous pulse (JVP) and its correlation with the cardiac cycle and electrocardiogram (ECG) findings. The discussion emphasized the events following the 'a' wave of the JVP.

 

  1. Rapid ejection
  2. R wave
  3. 1st Heart Sound
  4. T wave in ECG
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2  3  1  4

 

Option C. The R wave on the ECG corresponds to ventricular depolarization, followed by the first heart sound, which is due to the closure of the atrioventricular valves. Rapid ejection then occurs as the ventricles contract and eject blood, which is last phase of systole, followed by the T wave, indicating ventricular repolarization.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Incorrect. Rapid ejection which is last phase of systole follows the first heart sound, not preceding it. The first heart sound is associated with the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves, occurring after the R wave.
 

Option B. Incorrect. The T wave represents ventricular repolarization and follows the first heart sound and rapid ejection phase, not preceding the first heart sound.
 

Option D. Incorrect. The T wave occurs after rapid ejection and is not followed by another cardiac cycle event from this sequence. It represents the end of the ventricular repolarization phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the correlation between the jugular venous pulse, the cardiac cycle, and the ECG, particularly the sequence of events following the 'a' wave of the JVP.

 

Refer: Ganongs Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg No: 540

choices.text: Increased in HR decrease relaxation
Increased in HR increase relaxation
Increased in HR decrease contraction
Increased in HR increases contraction

questions.text: In a cardiology seminar, a thought-provoking case of a patient with tachycardia and its effects on myocardial function is presented to illustrate the physiological phenomenon known as Bowditch's effect, or the "Treppe" or "staircase" phenomenon.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased in HR increases contraction

 

Option D. Bowditch's effect, or the staircase phenomenon, describes how the heart's contractile force increases with an increase in HR, up to a physiological limit. This is thought to be due to a more efficient calcium handling by cardiac cells with more frequent stimulation.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Incorrect. While an increased heart rate (HR) can affect relaxation times, Bowditch's effect specifically refers to the relationship between HR and the strength of contraction, not directly to relaxation.
 

Option B. Incorrect. Increased HR leading to increased relaxation is not a characteristic of Bowditch's effect; rather, the effect pertains to the contractility of the heart muscle in response to increased HR.
 

Option C. Incorrect. Bowditch's effect actually describes the opposite phenomenon; as the HR increases, the strength of myocardial contractions tends to increase as well, not decrease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand Bowditch's effect, which posits that an increase in heart rate leads to an increase in the strength of myocardial contraction.

 

Refer: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg No: 522; Cardiovascular physiology concepts 2nd Edition, Pg No:82

choices.text: 4 liters/min
5.5 liters/min
9 liters/min
7.5 liters/min

questions.text: During a cardiology research meeting, a complex case study is presented involving the calculation of cardiac output in a patient with suspected heart failure. The patient's oxygen consumption is 300 ml/min; mixed arterial and mixed venous blood oxygen concentrations are 16 ml/dl and 20 ml/dl, challenging the team to apply their knowledge. What will be the value of the cardiac output in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 7.5 liters/min

 

Option D. Correct. Using the Fick principle,

 

 

Cardiac Output = O2 Consumption / Arteriovenous O2 Content Difference              

                           =300 ml/min / (20−16) ml/100 ml

                           =7.5 liters/min

 

aligning with the provided oxygen consumption and oxygen content difference.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A, Option B, Option C: Incorrect. The given values are inconsistent with the patient's data.  

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apply the Fick principle to calculate cardiac output using oxygen consumption and the difference in oxygen content between arterial and mixed venous blood.

 

(Refer: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, pg no: 532)

choices.text: Fast sodium channels
Voltage-gated potassium channels
L-type calcium channels
Ligand-gated calcium channels

questions.text: A 50-year-old female with a history of dilated cardiomyopathy is undergoing an educational session with her cardiologist to understand the electrophysiological changes in her heart. The cardiologist uses a diagram of the cardiac action potential to explain how different channels contribute to each phase, which of the following channels are responsible for the phase marked in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) L-type calcium channels


Option C. L-type calcium channels are responsible for the prolonged influx of calcium ions during the plateau phase (phase 2) of the cardiac action potential, which is indicated by the green arrow in the diagram.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Incorrect. Fast sodium channels are responsible for the rapid upstroke of the action potential (phase 0), not the plateau phase.


Option B. Incorrect. Voltage-gated potassium channels contribute to repolarization phases (phase 3), not the plateau (phase 2) marked by the green arrow.


Option D. Incorrect. Ligand-gated calcium channels are not primarily responsible for the action potential phases in cardiac muscle cells; the plateau phase is mediated by voltage-gated L-type calcium channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify the role of L-type calcium channels in the plateau phase of the cardiac muscle action potential.

 

 

Refer: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg No: 521

choices.text: Decrease in length and increase in diameter of the vessel with decreased blood viscosity will increase resistance.
Increase in length and diameter of the vessel with decreased blood viscosity will decrease resistance.
Increase in length and viscosity of the blood with decreased diameter of the vessel will decrease resistance.
Increase in length and viscosity of the blood with decreased diameter of the vessel will increase resistance.

questions.text: A 59-year-old female with diabetes and chronic kidney disease is evaluated for worsening symptoms of peripheral artery disease, which is causing significant exercise intolerance. The interventional cardiologist considers the impact of various physiological changes on vascular resistance in her lower extremities, using the Poiseuille-Hagen equation. Which of the following depicts it accurately in healthy adult?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase in length and viscosity of the blood with decreased diameter of the vessel will increase resistance.


Option D. According to the Poiseuille-Hagen equation, resistance is directly proportional to vessel length and blood viscosity and inversely proportional to the fourth power of the vessel's radius (or diameter). Therefore, an increase in length and viscosity with a decreased diameter would all contribute to an increase in vascular resistance.

 

The mathematical expression of this equation will be

 

F (flow) = (PA PB) /8 1/ r4/L

 

where F refers to the flow, PA PB refers to the pressure difference between the tube ends, refers to the viscosity of the fluid, r refers to the radius (diameter divided by 2) of the tube and L refers to the length of the tube.

 

 

formula for R Resistance ; Viscosity ; r radius ; L - length

 

Explanation:


Option A. Incorrect. Decreasing the length and increasing the diameter of a vessel would lead to a decrease in resistance, while decreased blood viscosity would further reduce resistance, not increase it.


Option B. Incorrect. Increasing the length of a vessel would increase resistance, while increasing the diameter would decrease resistance. Decreased blood viscosity would also decrease resistance, resulting in conflicting impacts on resistance.


Option C. Incorrect. An increase in length and blood viscosity would both increase resistance, whereas a decrease in vessel diameter would also increase resistance, not decrease it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the relationship between vessel length, blood viscosity, and vessel diameter on vascular resistance as described by the Poiseuille-Hagen equation, particularly in the context of peripheral artery disease.

 

Refer: Ganongs Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg No: 573

choices.text: The aorta facilitates gas exchange due to its permeability; capillaries exhibit Windkessel effect, veins show maximum smooth muscle presence affecting blood distribution, and arterioles act as blood reservoirs due to compliance.

Capillaries exhibit the Windkessel effect, veins facilitate gas exchange due to permeability, arterioles have a blood reservoir function due to compliance, and the aorta has maximum smooth muscle presence for blood distribution.

Veins show the Windkessel effect, arterioles facilitate gas exchange due to permeability, the aorta acts as a blood reservoir due to compliance, and capillaries have maximum smooth muscle presence for blood distribution.

The aorta has the Windkessel effect, capillaries facilitate gas exchange due to their permeability, veins act as blood reservoirs due to compliance, and arterioles have maximum smooth muscle presence to regulate blood distribution.

questions.text: A 78-year-old male with a history of hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is admitted for the management of congestive heart failure. The teaching hospital uses this case to detail the unique functional attributes of different blood vessels in maintaining circulatory homeostasis and the pathophysiology of the patient's condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The aorta has the Windkessel effect aiding in diastolic blood pressure, capillaries facilitate gas exchange due to their permeability, veins act as blood reservoirs due to compliance, and arterioles have maximum smooth muscle presence to regulate blood distribution.

 

Option D. The aorta exhibits the Windkessel effect, which is important for dampening the pulsatile nature of blood flow from the heart and aiding in diastolic blood pressure. Capillaries allow for gas exchange due to their permeability. Veins, due to their compliance, can accommodate various blood volumes, acting as reservoirs. Arterioles, with their significant smooth muscle content, are key in regulating blood distribution to various tissues.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Incorrect. The aorta does not facilitate gas exchange; this is the function of capillaries. The Windkessel effect is characteristic of large elastic arteries like the aorta, not capillaries, and veins are compliant to act as blood reservoirs, not arterioles.
 

Option B. Incorrect. Capillaries do not exhibit the Windkessel effect; this is seen in the aorta. Veins are not primarily for gas exchange but for blood return to the heart, and arterioles regulate blood flow, not act as reservoirs.
 

Option C. Incorrect. Veins do not show the Windkessel effect; this is a property of the aorta. Arterioles, not the aorta, are responsible for the distribution of blood due to their muscular walls and not for acting as blood reservoirs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the unique functional properties of different types of blood vessels: the Windkessel effect of the aorta, permeability of capillaries for gas exchange, compliance of veins for blood storage, and the role of arterioles in blood distribution.

 

Refer: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg No: 568, 569

choices.text: Sonali observed an increase in MBP, but Mitali noted a decrease in MBP.
Sonali noted a decrease in MBP, but Mitali observed an increase in MBP.
Both Sonali and Mitali recorded an increase in MBP.
Both Sonali and Mitali recorded a decrease in MBP.

questions.text: In a clinical research trial two medical students, Sonali and Mitali, were tasked with demonstrating the effect of the sinus nerve on blood pressure regulation during induced hypovolemic shock in canines. Sonali severed the sinus nerve at a mean blood pressure (MBP) of 85 mm Hg, while Mitali did the same when the MBP was 50 mm Hg. Following the severance of the sinus nerve:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sonali observed an increase in MBP, but Mitali noted a decrease in MBP.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Correct. Sonali, who severed (i.e. cut or sliced off) the sinus nerve at a higher MBP of 85 mm Hg, observed an increase in MBP due to the removal of baroreceptor-mediated inhibition on the vasomotor center, which is active at this pressure. Mitali, on the other hand, noted a decrease in MBP because at 60 mm Hg, the baroreceptors are largely inactive; therefore, cutting the sinus nerve removed the chemoreceptor-driven sympathetic stimulation, leading to a decrease in MBP.

 

Sonali: At 85 mm Hg: during this time Baroreceptors are still active Physiologically (in a lesser degree). Active Baroreceptor decreases BP So, cutting the sinus nerve during this time, all inhibitory effect on VMC will be lost, Baroreceptors cannot decrease the BP hence BP will rise (although rise will not be very severe). 

 

Mitali: At 60 mm Hg: during this time Baroreceptors are completely inactive, but chemoreceptors are active Physiologically. Active chemoreceptor increases BP So, cutting the sinus nerve during this time, excitatory effect on VMC due to chemoreceptor will be lost and Chemoreceptors cannot increase the BP hence BP will fall.

 

Option B, Option C, Option D. Incorrect

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the role of the sinus nerve in modulating blood pressure through baroreceptor and chemoreceptor activity and how its severance affects MBP at different pressures during hypovolemic shock.

 

Refer: Ganongs Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg No: 588

choices.text: Bezold Jarisch reflex induces tachycardia in response to right atrial distension.
Bainbridge reflex is responsible for tachycardia following right atrial distension.
Cushing reflex triggers tachycardia due to increased intracranial pressure, not atrial distension.
J reflex is associated with pulmonary receptors responding to congestion, not directly causing tachycardia due to right atrial distension.

questions.text: A 72-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and right heart failure is admitted with signs of volume overload. During her assessment, the medical team observes an increase in her heart rate correlated with episodes of coughing and jugular venous distension. Which one of the following reflex mechanisms that might be contributing to patient’s condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bainbridge reflex is responsible for tachycardia following right atrial distension.


Option B. The Bainbridge reflex is activated by the stretch of receptors in the right atrium due to increased venous return or RA distension, leading to a reflex increase in heart rate to accommodate the increased blood volume and prevent venous congestion.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Incorrect. The Bezold Jarisch reflex typically results in bradycardia, hypotension, and vasodilation in response to ventricular ischemia or infarction, not tachycardia due to right atrial distension.


Option C. Incorrect. The Cushing reflex is a physiological response to increased intracranial pressure, characterized by hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration, and is unrelated to right atrial distension.


Option D. Incorrect. The J reflex, or pulmonary inflation reflex, is triggered by stimulation of J receptors in the lungs, leading to rapid, shallow breathing in response to pulmonary congestion or edema, but it does not directly cause tachycardia due to right atrial distension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that the Bainbridge reflex is triggered by right atrial distension, leading to an increase in heart rate as a compensatory mechanism to manage increased venous return.

 

Refer: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Pg No : 225,226, 227)

choices.text: Laminar flow in small vessels is due to a Reynolds number greater than 2000,
The large cross-sectional area of small vessels being smaller contributes to laminar flow.
The larger diameter of vessels inherently results in laminar flow.
Laminar flow in small vessels is attributed to lower effective velocity.

questions.text: A 49-year-old researcher is studying the characteristics of blood flow in various vascular beds to better understand the mechanisms behind targeted drug delivery systems. In a discussion about why certain nanoparticles exhibit preferential accumulation in smaller capillaries, the concept of laminar flow. In regard to this, which one of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laminar flow in small vessels is attributed to lower effective velocity, which reduces the likelihood of turbulence.


Option D.  Laminar flow in small vessels is facilitated by lower effective velocities, which contribute to lower Reynolds numbers, reducing the risk of turbulence. In smaller vessels like capillaries, the slow velocity allows blood to flow in a streamlined manner, with minimal crosscurrents or eddies.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Incorrect. A Reynolds number greater than 2000 indicates a transition to turbulent flow, not laminar. Laminar flow occurs at lower Reynolds numbers, where fluid layers move smoothly in parallel.


Option B. Incorrect. While the total cross-sectional area of small vessels is larger (not smaller) since numerous small vessels are arranged in parallel, hence this factor does not explain laminar flow. Laminar flow is more directly influenced by the velocity and viscosity of the blood, as well as the vessel diameter.
 

Option C. Incorrect. The larger diameter of vessels inherently results in turbulent flow. According to Reynold’s number formula

 

 

(where ρ is the density of the blood, v is the mean velocity, D is the diameter, and μ is the viscosity).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that laminar flow in small vessels is facilitated by lower effective velocities, which keep the Reynolds number low, promoting smooth, parallel layers of fluid movement.

 

 

Refer: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg No: 571,573

choices.text: The flow rate in vessel A is 4 times that of vessel B.
The flow rate in vessel A is 8 times that of vessel B.
The flow rate in vessel A is 16 times that of vessel B.
The flow rate in vessel A is 32 times that of vessel B.

questions.text: In a vascular research lab, an experiment is conducted to study the effects of vessel diameter and length on blood flow rates. Two artificial vessels, A and B, are set up for comparison. Vessel A has a diameter of 2D and a length of 2L, whereas vessel B has a diameter of D and a length of L. Calculate the flow rate of vessel A relative to vessel B.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The flow rate in vessel A is 8 times that of vessel B.

 

Explanation:

 

 

  • According to Poiseuille-Hagen equation,

 

F (flow) = (PA – PB ) × π r4/8 ηL

               = r4/ L

               = (2) 4 / 2       = 16/ 2       = 8

 

F is the flow rate, ΔP is the pressure difference, r is the radius (half of the diameter), η is the viscosity, and L is the length of the vessel. Doubling the diameter (and thus the radius).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that according to Poiseuille's law, the flow rate through a vessel is affected by both the diameter (radius) and the length of the vessel. In this case, doubling the diameter increases the flow rate by 16 times, but doubling the length reduces it by half, resulting in a net increase of 8 times in the flow rate for vessel A compared to vessel B.

 

Refer: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg No: 571

choices.text: The 'a' wave correlates with ventricular systole, as it reflects atrial contraction.
The 'v' wave occurs during ventricular diastole and corresponds to the filling of the atrium against a closed tricuspid valve.
The 'c' wave represents rapid ventricular ejection and occurs immediately after the 'a' wave.
The 'x' descent is seen during ventricular systole and is associated with atrial contraction and downward displacement of the tricuspid valve.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of congestive heart failure presents with worsening dyspnea and peripheral edema. During the examination, the attending cardiologist notes prominent jugular venous pulsations. Which of the following shows the accurate correlation between JVP waves and the cardiac cycle.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The 'v' wave occurs during ventricular diastole and corresponds to the filling of the atrium against a closed tricuspid valve.

 

Option B.  The 'v' wave in the JVP is observed during ventricular diastole and results from the filling of the atrium against a closed tricuspid valve, leading to a rise in atrial pressure that is transmitted to the jugular veins.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Incorrect. The 'a' wave in the JVP reflects atrial contraction, but it occurs during late ventricular diastole, just before ventricular systole, not during ventricular systole itself.
 

Option C. Incorrect. The 'c' wave in the JVP does not represent rapid ventricular ejection; instead, it occurs due to the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole, causing a slight elevation in atrial pressure.
 

Option D. Incorrect. The 'x' descent follows the 'a' wave and represents atrial relaxation and the downward displacement of the closed tricuspid valve during ventricular systole, not associated with atrial contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the correlation between the waves of the jugular venous pulse (JVP) and the cardiac cycle, particularly how the 'v' wave reflects atrial filling against a closed tricuspid valve during ventricular diastole.

 

Refer: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 26th edition, Pg no: 531

choices.text: Hemorrhage typically leads to decreased blood pressure due to blood loss and compensatory hypertension.
High altitude causes hypoxic vasodilation, which can lead to high blood pressure, and low heart rate.
Raised intracranial pressure can trigger increased blood pressure and decreased heart rate, to maintain cerebral perfusion.
Anemia often results in decreased blood viscosity, leading to reduced peripheral resistance and potentially increasing blood pressure, with compensatory bradycardia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a recent history of head trauma is admitted to the emergency department with signs of deteriorating consciousness, hypertension and bradycardia. The neurology team is concerned about this condition. Such condition can be seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Raised intracranial pressure can trigger increased blood pressure and decreased heart rate, to maintain cerebral perfusion.


Option C: Raised intracranial pressure can initiate the Cushing reflex, a protective mechanism characterized by hypertension and bradycardia. This response aims to increase cerebral perfusion pressure in the face of elevated ICP, aligning with the patient's presentation.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Incorrect. Hemorrhage results in blood loss, leading to decreased blood pressure, not hypertension. The body compensates with tachycardia (increased heart rate), not bradycardia, in an attempt to maintain cardiac output and perfusion.


Option B. Incorrect. High altitude exposure leads to hypoxic vasodilation, generally resulting in lower blood pressure. The typical physiological response includes an increased heart rate to enhance oxygen delivery, not bradycardia.


Option D. Incorrect. Anemia leads to decreased blood viscosity and reduced peripheral resistance, which can lower blood pressure. The body's compensatory response usually involves tachycardia to increase oxygen delivery, not bradycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that the combination of hypertension and bradycardia in a patient with signs of deteriorating consciousness, particularly following head trauma, suggests raised intracranial pressure, indicative of the Cushing reflex.

 

Refer: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 26th edition, pg no: 582

choices.text: Point B, when the aortic valve is open and the blood is being ejected into the aorta.
Point C, at the peak of systolic pressure within the aorta.
Point D, during the closing of the aortic valve.
Point E, in the phase of isovolumic relaxation.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease is undergoing a routine echocardiogram that shows a normal aortic pressure waveform and the timing of coronary blood flow during the cardiac cycle. At which point on the aortic pressure waveform diagram provided is the coronary blood flow the greatest?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Point E, in the phase of isovolumic relaxation.


Option D:  Coronary blood flow is at its greatest during early diastole (Point E), when the heart muscle is relaxed and the aortic pressure is still relatively high, which facilitates blood flow into the coronary circulation.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Incorrect. During systolic ejection (Point B), coronary blood flow to the myocardium is not at its peak due to the compression of the coronary arteries by the contracting heart muscle.


Option B. Incorrect. At the peak of the systolic pressure (Point C), the coronary vessels are still compressed by the contracting myocardium, which impedes blood flow to the heart muscle.


Option C. Incorrect. As the aortic valve closes (Point D), there is a brief period where coronary blood flow is not maximal due to ongoing myocardial contraction and resultant coronary vessel compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that the greatest coronary blood flow occurs early in diastole during isovolumic relaxation, when ventricular pressure decreases, reducing compression of the coronary arteries, and the aortic pressure is still high enough to drive blood into the coronary vessels.

 

Refer: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 26th edition, pg no: 599

choices.text: Volume receptors are primarily influenced by total cardiovascular output and modulate renal function accordingly.
Volume receptors are activated by changes in atrial pressure during systole and diastole, influencing diuresis and sodium retention.
Volume receptors respond directly to left ventricular contraction strength, adjusting peripheral resistance and heart rate.
Volume receptors are sensitive to fluctuations in aortic pressure, thereby regulating arterial blood volume.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure is admitted to the cardiology unit with symptoms of worsening dyspnea and peripheral edema. The medical team is monitoring her closely for signs of volume overload, which one of the following represents the role of volume receptors in fluid regulation and their response to changes in cardiac function.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Volume receptors are activated by changes in atrial pressure during systole and diastole, influencing diuresis and sodium retention.

 

Option B: Volume receptors, especially those in the atria, are stimulated by stretching during atrial systole and diastole. This activation plays a critical role in the regulation of fluid balance by influencing renal function via Atrial Natriuretic Peptide, including diuresis and sodium retention mechanisms.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Incorrect. While total cardiovascular output can influence volume status, volume receptors, particularly those located in the atria, respond more directly to changes in atrial pressure rather than the overall cardiovascular output.
 

Option C. Incorrect. Although left ventricular contraction affects cardiac output but volume receptors are more directly stimulated by changes in atrial pressures rather than by ventricular contraction per se and it cannot adjust peripheral resistance and heart rate.
 

Option D. Incorrect. Volume receptors in the atria and pulmonary vasculature are more directly influenced by changes in venous return and atrial pressures, not specifically by aortic pressure. Aortic baroreceptors, which respond to aortic pressure, are more involved in blood pressure regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the role of atrial volume receptors in sensing changes in atrial pressure during systole and diastole, contributing to fluid balance regulation through effects on renal function.

 

Refer: Ganongs Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg No: 591

choices.text: Fourth heart sound is associated with ventricular systole and follows the second heart sound.
Fourth heart sound precedes the first heart sound and is related to late diastolic filling.
Fourth heart sound occurs immediately after the first heart sound and signifies atrial contraction.
Fourth heart sound coincides with the rapid ejection phase of the ventricles and precedes the second heart sound.

questions.text: In a cardiology masterclass focusing on advanced cardiac auscultation, the discussion turns to the nuances of heart sounds and their timing within the cardiac cycle. The participants are asked to identify the correct association of the fourth heart sound with a specific phase of cardiac activity and its typical sequence in relation to other heart sounds. Which of the following statements is accurate regarding it?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fourth heart sound precedes the first heart sound and is related to late diastolic filling.

 

Option B. Correct. S4 is indeed a diastolic sound, occurring just before S1, associated with the atria contracting and pushing blood into the ventricles during late diastolic filling, often in the context of ventricular stiffness or decreased compliance. It can be heard when atrial pressure is increased or in conditions like ventricular hypertrophy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. fourth heart sound (S4) is not associated with ventricular systole, nor does it follow S2. It is an atrial sound that occurs during late diastole, just before S1.

 

Option C. Incorrect. While S4 signifies atrial contraction, it does not occur after S1 but rather precedes it, marking the final phase of ventricular filling just before ventricular systole begins.

 

Option D. Incorrect. S4 is not related to the rapid ejection phase, which occurs during systole after S1. S4 is a pre-systolic sound associated with the final phase of diastolic ventricular filling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the timing and physiological basis of the fourth heart sound (S4) in relation to the cardiac cycle, emphasizing its occurrence during late diastole and its association with atrial contraction.

Refer: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia Edition, Pg No : 213

questions.text:
A 58-year-old female with a history of chronic anxiety presents to the clinic complaining of intermittent palpitations and shortness of breath. She notes that her symptoms often improve with rest and deep breathing exercises. A 24-hour Holter monitor demonstrates episodes of bradycardia correlating with her symptoms. The cardiologist discusses the effects of the parasympathetic nervous system on her heart function. Which of the following depict the scenario correctly?

 

  1. Decreased heart rate
  2. Decreased cardiac output
  3. Prolonged R-R interval
  4. Increased force of contraction
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1,2,3


Option C. Parasympathetic stimulation decreases heart rate (1), which can lead to decreased cardiac output (2), especially if the decrease in rate is significant, and consequently prolongs the R-R interval on ECG (3), reflecting the slower heart rate.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Incorrect. While parasympathetic stimulation does decrease heart rate and cardiac output, this option does not include the prolonged R-R interval which is a direct consequence of a decreased heart rate.


Option B. Incorrect. Parasympathetic stimulation leads to a decrease, not an increase, in the force of contraction. Prolonged R-R interval is correct, but it should be paired with decreased heart rate and cardiac output.


Option D. Incorrect. Increased force of contraction is not a result of parasympathetic stimulation. On the contrary, parasympathetic activity typically has little to no direct effect on the force of contraction in the ventricles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the effects of parasympathetic stimulation on the heart, which include decreased heart rate, decreased cardiac output, and prolonged R-R interval on an ECG.

 

 

Refer: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th Edition, Pg No: 586

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents to clinic for a routine health check-up. He has no significant past medical history and leads an active lifestyle. During his respiratory examination, you note the following parameters: His respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, tidal volume is measured at 400 mL, and dead space volume is estimated to be 150 mL. What is the patient's alveolar ventilation per minute?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4000 mL

 

Explanation:

 

Option C:

 

  • The alveolar ventilation per minute can be defined as the total volume of new air entering the alveoli in one minute.
  • The alveolar ventilation per minute can be expressed as
    • Alveolar ventilation per min = (Tidal volume - dead space) x rate of respiration
    • Here, tidal volume = 400 mL, respiratory rate = 16/min
    • Dead space volume = 150 mL
    • Alveolar ventilation/min = (400 - 150) x 16 = 250 x 16 = 4000 mL

 

#Extra edge: Types of Dead Spaces –

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand and accurately calculate alveolar ventilation rates using patient respiratory parameters.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia Edition, Pg No: 34

Decreased FEV1, Decreased FEV1/FVC
Increased FEV1, Decreased FEV1/FVC

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a four-week history of progressive breathlessness. He reports episodes of wheezing, especially at night and early in the morning. His past medical history includes occasional allergic rhinitis but no prior episodes of similar symptoms. On physical examination, you note expiratory wheezing bilaterally. He denies any history of smoking. A spirometry test is conducted diagnosis of bronchial asthma was made. Based on the clinical presentation and diagnosis, which of the following spirometry findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased FEV1, Decreased FEV1/FVC

 

  • This is a case of bronchial asthma (obstructive lung disease)

  • FVC refers to forced vital capacity, FEV refers to forced expiratory volume and FEV1 refers to forced expiratory volume in 1st second.

  • In obstructive lung diseases like bronchial asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), the FEV1 will be decreased and the ratio of FEV1/FVC will also be decreased due to obstruction of the airflow in the lungs.

  • Lung disease measurements:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize decreased FVC and decreased FEV1/FVC ratio in spirometry as indicative of bronchial asthma in symptomatic patients.

 

Ref: Ganongs Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg No: 630

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to your clinic for a routine physical examination. He is a non-smoker with no significant past medical history. As part of the examination, you perform a spirometry test. The results show a tidal volume of 460 mL and an inspiratory capacity of 3380 mL. He also has a known expiratory reserve volume of 1060 mL. Calculate his IRV.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2920 mL

 

Explanation:

 

  • The additional volume of air that can be inspired above the tidal respiration is termed as Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV)
  • The Inspiratory Capacity (IC) can be defined as the sum of the tidal volume (TV) and the inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

 

Here, tidal volume = 460 mL,

 

inspiratory capacity = 3380 mL

 

IC = TV + IRV

 

IRV = IC – TV = 3380 - 460 = 2920 mL

 

# Lung volumes and capacity measurements. Lung volumes recorded by a spirometer. Lung capacities are determined from volume recordings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Inspiratory Capacity (IC) can be defined as the sum of the Tidal Volume (TV) and the Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV)

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg no: 629

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is breathing quietly. He then inhales as much air as possible and exhales as much air as he can, producing the spirogram shown in the previous figure. What is his Expiratory Reserve Volume (in Liters)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2.0

 

Explanation:

 

  • The Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) is the maximum extra volume of air that can be expired by forceful expiration after the end of a normal tidal expiration.
  • ERV is equal to the difference between the Functional Residual Capacity (FRC, 3 L) and the Residual Volume (RV, 1 L).
     

ERV = FRC – RV

= 3L – 1L    = 2L

 

# Lung volumes and capacity measurements. Lung volumes recorded by a spirometer. Lung capacities are determined from volume recordings.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The objective of this question is to test understanding of lung volumes and capacities, particularly the corelation of FRC, ERV and RV in a graph format.

questions.text:
A patient with chronic respiratory symptoms is undergoing a diagnostic workup. The attending pulmonologist is reviewing Weibel's classification of the bronchial tree with the medical team to assist in the localization of the pathology. Match the correct generation of bronchioles to their defining characteristics as per Weibel's model:

 

Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-2, B-1, C-3, D-4


Correct Matches:

 

 

Explanation:

 

  • Statement A: Generation 7 - Main Bronchi (2): This generation, consisting of the main bronchi, has cartilaginous rings and is part of the purely conducting airway, indicating the option for the main bronchi.

 

  • Statement B: Generation 12 - Terminal bronchioles (1): As the final segment of the conducting airways, the terminal bronchioles are correctly matched with generation 12, which is immediately prior to the respiratory portion of the airways.

 

  • Statement C: Generation 17 - Respiratory bronchioles (3): The transitional bronchioles at generation 17, where the first alveoli appear, match the respiratory bronchioles, marking the beginning of the respiratory zone.

 

  • Statement D: Generation 23 - Alveolar sacs (4): This generation is well within the respiratory zone and includes the alveolar sacs, where extensive gas exchange takes place, making it the correct match for the alveolar sacs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The aim is to challenge the learner’s ability to integrate complex anatomical knowledge of the bronchial tree with clinical concepts, using Weibel's classification for precise localization of pulmonary lesions.

 

 

 

(Refer : Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, pg. no : 610, 611)

Question level: Intermediate.
